data.title: Dinner
data.text: I had the Tuscan Salmon with pasta. Excellent. The tapas served prior to our meal were delicious. Nice presentation. The atmosphere is very nice. It's an old church. It has a beautiful courtyard to sip wine and relax. My only reason for not going a full 5 on the rating was the opinion of others that their New York steak was ok but not fabulous enough for the cost. It's not a budget meal place. Meals are $20 and up. The steak was over $40. I will be back for that Salmon and the tapas.

data.title: Great food excellent nice place
data.text: Noticed they were open so my wife and I decided to try it as it is downtown and close to our office. Service was just OK I had a Bloody Mary and it was terrible. Cheap vodka and zero effort. The food on the other hand was exceptional. Stuffed dates were so good I wanted to order some to go. I had Chicken Picatta It was very good. Apps were great. We will be back. Hopefully the bar tender will care about their drinks a bit more by the next time we go. It is in an old church so the décor is great and the stain glass was beautiful.

data.title: Very Good New Restaurant
data.text:
Our party of 3 couples visited the Ivy for dinner.  The service was excellent.  The menu is varied from sandwhiches to wraps to tapas to kabobs to pasta & pizza to entres like steak and salmon.  It has full bar service and a nice wine list.
Appetizers are served with pita bread at each table and they include items such as pickled beans, pickled mushrooms, and humus.  Of special note is a spicy red spread which goes very well with the pita bread.
Portions are generous and the food is well prepared.  Every one of the 6 meals were tasty - there was no disappointment in any of the meals.  Our group had beef kabobs, rack of lamb, salmon, and pasta.  My wife had the French onion soup which was outstanding.
The ambience is classy, quiet, and relaxing.  I highly recommend this restaurant for both lunch and dinner.

data.title: I love luch, small plates and sharing...The Ivy is a great place to do all three...
data.text: I have a foodie friend and we make it our business to try a new place or test a new cuisine at least once every 3 weeks or so. We have  gone ritzy and we have gone dive bar-y and The Ivy was our latest find. Located in an repurposed church the room is expansive and bright. We each chose an item off the 12 dollar lunch menu.   I had the ground beef kebobs and my friend ordered the chicken picata. Every meal starts off with the delivery of six small plates of mediterrnean tapas to share,  Ours included eggplant, Turkish salad, pickled cabbage, corn salad hummus and pita. So much fun to sample and compare. My kebobs were rendolent of mint and spices and my friend's picata was flavorfull and fresh. Service was excellent. My friend and I have promised to only try new places so I will have to sneak back with other friends....shhhhh...don't tell on me...but I will be back

data.title: Delightful Place
data.text: I have eaten here for both lunch and dinner.  Do love the appetizer selection that comes with the meal. One thing that seems a problem...there seems to be a really long lag time for service.  Severs seem to have too many duties (bartender AND server in the dining room).  Also don't care for the pita bread they serve...been spoiled by the fresh pita over at Cafe Med across town.  Just my personal preference.  Have enjoyed the oxtail stew that comes in a personalized dutch oven...it is fantastic.  Beef dishes have been delicious, but the lamb kabobs were tough and had gristle...not what I was going for.  The setting is so wonderful, and is a great place for a celebration, since they can accommodate a pretty large group, and allow them to actually talk. I keep going back and there are improvements at each visit.  Hope they keep it up and will eventually work out any kinks.

data.title: Before the Concert
data.text: We were very happy with the way the outside patio seating looked and the bar was small but fun. The restaurant looked a little tired.  The food was ok. Had a few minor problems with the way it was cooked. Manager was very attentive and made us happy. Will try again.

data.title: Not ready for prime time
data.text:
We've been looking forward to trying this relatively new spot. It was a disappointment. I've never started a restaurant review talking about ambiance. But this place is so lacking in that regard, I have to start there because it hits you in the face as soon as you walk in the dining room. The walls need painting and some kind, any kind, of artwork, fixtures, something. The tables are dark wood, some round, some square, none with table clothes. Even the napkins are dark, so they offer no contrast or color, either. The lighter wood chairs, which are on wheels and don't go with the tables, look like they came from a 1970s Holiday Inn coffee shop. The lights were too bright for dinner time and the temperature in the room almost required a sweater. The whole scene was bland and unappealing. 

The setting wasn't helped by the fact that only one other table, out of about 20, was occupied. One table on the outside patio, which is quite nice, was occupied but the people there were smoking so we opted not to go out there. A couple of other people were at the bar, as was the person who appeared to be the manager.

The tapas setup, which is brought to every table is nice and tasty. We enjoyed it. We then ordered a Mediterranean sampler plate as an appetizer, which was pretty good but none of the items were particularly noteworthy. For our entree, we split an order of the lobster ravioli. Some of the pasta was cooked properly, while other pieces of it were almost dry and yellowed, as if those had been prepared well before the other or had been left under a warming light far too long. The filling in the ravioli was very good but its delicate taste was completely overwhelmed by the heavy tomato cream sauce on which the pasta was served. That sauce was good on its own, but it wasn't compatible with the ravioli. For dessert we tried the chocolate cheese cake. It, too, seemed tired and shelf weary. Between the two of us, we ate no more than half of it. I had coffee and my wife had Baileys and coffee and both were served barely lukewarm.

The highlight of the evening was the service. It was outstanding (thank you, Pauline); very friendly and attentive. But, given our other choices in town and this first experience, we're not likely to return to enjoy the service.

data.title: Just Okay
data.text:
Been here a few times since they opened.  Food is just ok.  I have tried a few different dishes, all have been decent, but nothing spectacular.  The tapas style set up is pretty neat, but again, nothing great.  

The biggest negative for me is the service.  Once you get service, its fine, but getting there is the problem.  I've never been in and out of the restaurant in an hour.  If you're due back in Court at 1:30, good luck making your appearance!  Unfortunate, too, because The Ivy is right across from the Justice Center and Superior Court, great to draw in attorneys and judges, but the poor service/wait times is what probably keeps them out.  

I really want to like this place, but I just don't think I'm going to.

data.title: for something out of the ordinary
data.text: The Ivy is a newer addition to the restaurant scene in Bakersfield.  The Tapas allow you try different offerings and find your favorites.  The portions are plentiful without being overly large.  I don't like to leave food on plate and some dishes do not travel well.

data.title: Eureka !  Great new Bakersfield Restaurant
data.text:
Great new Bakersfield restaurant.  Could be a real five star restaurant with a little improvement in service.  For of us ate there on a Saturday night.  The Ivy is located in an old Baptist Church that has been completely renovated!

We arrived at 5:00pm.  Promptly seated.  They indicated they start the meal service with tapas.  Not really true.  five or six Mediterranean type dips, not actual tapas.....

Anyho....waiter promptly took order. I ordered shrimp kabobs with a side of spaghetti. Both five star.  Spouse ordered Lamb Kabobs and roasted potatoes. She loved her dish.  16 yo old ordered chicken Alfredo...said it was as good as his Grandma's...a real compliant.  oldest grandson ordered s steak, medium, came not rare but raw. yuk.  we took it home and re-heated it.  Grandson ordered a side of fries and I ordered a Brussel sprout concoction.  Both were delicious except the waited forgot to put the order in and they did not arrive until the end of the meal!  They kept the "tapas" dishes full and replenished the warm pita bread. Overall a great dining experience.

Hopefully the owner/manager will read and make the slight improvements and this will be a five star restaurant!

data.title: My new favourite Bakersfield Restaurant!
data.text:
Went for my first visit to the Ivy today, and I loved it.  It's inside an old Baptist church, with beautiful stained glass windows, which gives it a cool factor even though the decor needs a little jazzing up.  The patio, however, was fantastic!  Has to be the best patio in Bakersfield.

Food was great!  We started out with tapas delivered to our table, which was a nice introduction.  House Chardonnay was decent and cold, and they had a great selection of beers.

I was pleased to see a number of vegetarian options on the menu - something that seems hard to find in Bakersfield.  I had the falafel wrap, and my lunch companions had the lamb wrap and lamb kabob.  All of it was delicious, and we finished off with creme brûlée, tiramisu and cheesecake for dessert.  

Service was friendly and personable, and we definitely felt like welcome guests.

It was a bit pricey for lunch - would be nice to see them implement a lunch menu.  However, prices were not unreasonable for a nice dinner.  Corkage and lots of parking are definite pluses also.

The Ivy fills a much needed niche in Bakersfield of a good, more upscale date night venue.  I look forward to returning!

data.title: Great food, great service
data.text: Seven ladies for lunch on a Wednesday at noon. Not busy, but this is a new restaurant and hasn't been open long. We all agreed the food was very good and we mostly ordered different things. I had the lamb kabobs and it was done perfectly. Two of them ordered the lamb wrap and were pleased with their order. The salads were fresh and as ordered. The tapas were complimentary with our orders and were very good, although the pita bread seemed to be lacking flavor. Parking is right outside the back door and very convenient. The service was excellent.

data.title: Unique location, great Mediterranean food!
data.text: Really great Mediterranean food in a historic, old church.  You are welcomed with fresh pita bread and a dozen or so tapas/ toppings for the bread!  The Greek salad was good!  Decent amount of food for the price!  Would definitely be great for happy hour!!

data.title: A bit slow, but worth the wait
data.text:
Three of us met for lunch and enjoyed a lovely meal at the courtyard tables. Our personable server presented us with an array of tapas-filled dishes and warm pita bread. He explained this was the "set up" and usually $10, but the charge is waived if meals are ordered. Our food was delicious -- lamb kabobs and sweet potato fries. The beer selection was extensive, but there was no gluten free beer on hand.

Service was a bit slow as we waited too long a time between the tapas delivery and when our drink order was taken. Once the food order was taken, the wait seemed reasonable.

Great menu with many things I will want to try the next time.

data.title: great aspirations,  very few glitches,  amazing 'setup'
data.text:
This placed used to house a members only restaurant,  but is open to the public now.  The place is strangely less formal, and yet pricier than the previous place.  They have a nice 'tapas' setup which arrives at your table in several (7?  8? 9?) little bowls with spoons and pita bread. the idea is to spread a little of the offerings on a piece of pita and indulge while your order is being prepared.  Items include a green pepper spicy spread, a reddish 'Turkish salad', beets, fava beans, eggplant, hummus & tahini ...... each in their little bowls (shared at the table).  on our first go round, the pita bread was cold and tough to chew, but a second helping arrived toasty warm and flexible.   I ordered the lamb kabob, and my companion ordered the Beef kabob.  each dish comes with a choice of 1 of the 4 'sides' listed : French Fries, Rice Pilaf, Rosemary Potatoes, and 'Basil,Tomato,Garlic' Pasta - referred to as 'BTG Pasta'   
I chose the Rosemary potatoes, which I found uninspiring.   My companion wanted none of those, but asked if he could substitute the Mushrooms from the Side Dishes section of the menu.  the waiter said there would be an additional charge. what he didn't say was you'll pay full price for the side dish ($7).   While the mushrooms were really good my companion would have preferred the rice pilaf and the $7 in his pocket. .... anyway - the kabobs were perfectly prepared. Both of us were very pleased with the presentation.   as this was a business lunch, we did not indulge in the wine choices, which are considerable.  nor did we try the desserts.
